raw_text:
Tindall wants second opinion
 
 England centre Mike Tindall is to seek a second opinion before having surgery on a foot injury that could force him to miss the entire Six Nations.
 
 The Bath player was already out of the opener against Wales on 5 February because of a hand problem. "Mike had a specialist review on a fracture in his right mid foot," said England doctor Simon Kemp. "Before a final decision is made on surgery... medical teams have decided he should see a second specialist."
 
 England coach Andy Robinson is already without centre Will Greenwood and flanker Richard Hill while fly-half Jonny Wilkinson is certain to miss at least the first two games. Robinson is expected to announce his new-look England line-up on Monday for the match at the Millennium Stadium. And Newcastle's 18-year-old centre Mathew Tait is set to stand in for Tindall alongside club team-mate Jamie Noon.
 
 Meanwhile, Tindall is targeting a return to action before the end of the regular Zurich Premiership season on 30 April. He will also aim to be back to full fitness before the Lions tour to New Zealand this summer.

The specialist review has decided he should see another doctor, and England coach Andy Robinson will announce a new-look team lineup for the match at the Millennium Stadium on Monday.

England coach Andy Robinson is without several key players, and Mathew Tait will likely start at center for England.
Tindall hopes to return before the end of the season and be fit for the Lions tour to New Zealand.

tinydolphin:1.1b: First, I need to summarize the content to ensure I am conveying the essence of the information accurately and in a way that is easy for you to understand.
Based on the provided text, Tindall wants to undergo a second opinion before having surgery on his foot.
This will be done to evaluate his recovery from an injury that may prevent him from participating in this season's Six Nations.
His absence could have significant implications for England's rugby team and may even force them to seek out alternative options in the upcoming matches.
In addition to Tindall, other players on England's roster are already sidelined due to injuries.
This includes Will Greenwood, who will need a second opinion before being cleared to play again.

It is also anticipated that national team coach Andy Robinson may announce his new lineup, including the players he intends to call up for the match against Newcastle's 18-year-old center Mathew Tait.
Meanwhile, Tindall himself will need to be fit enough to return to action before the end of the regular season in the Zurich Premiership.
If successful, he could potentially participate in the Lions tour to New Zealand later this summer.
